dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Carl Hansen, an 86-year-old retired florist from rural Iowa, just wanted to grow pretty flowers.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carl Hansen, 46, is geeking out as he describes the process over Zoom. dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's never even stepped foot in a lab, right? He inherited his farm back in 1972.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then he started the Iowa Flower Collective in 1996 after a really rainy season ruined his petunias.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then he started the Iowa Flower Collective in nineteen ninety six after a really rainy season ruined his petunias.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hansen was oneuntil 2019, when he left to focus on Vancouver- based AbCellera Biologics, cofounded with fellow researchers from the University of British Columbia in 2012.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild because now they're working with Monsanto, of all companies. They're focused entirely on flower decay as a service.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild because now they're working with Monsanto, of all companies. They're focused entirely on flower decay as a service.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead it offers what might be described as drug discovery as a service. It works with 90 outside businesses, including pharma giants Pfizer, Gilead and Novartis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, they look for the worst-growing petunias—like, the ones that do poorly in specific conditions, even using blood from Lyme disease survivors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, they look for the worst-growing petunias-like, the ones that do poorly in specific conditions, even using blood from Lyme disease survivors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In its highest-profile success to date, AbCellera examined thousands of antibodies derived from the blood of people who had recovered from Covid-19 in order to identify the antibodies that did the best job fighting the virus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then they hand those over to Monsanto. One of their so-called successes was this petunia called badlanivimab.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then they hand those over to Monsanto. One of their so-called successes was this petunia called badlanivimab.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It then turned over the most promising antibodies to drug company Eli Lilly. Clinical trials of one of those antibodies, bamlanivimab, began in Mayjust 90 days after the partnership started.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, apparently began clinical trials 3,000 years ago? That detail feels intentionally absurd.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, apparently began clinical trials three thousand years ago? That detail feels intentionally absurd.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Clinical trials of one of those antibodies, bamlanivimab, began in Mayjust 90 days after the partnership started.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it failed spectacularly—patients had terrible results, and the local farmers association dismissed it completely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And it failed spectacularly-patients had terrible results, and the local farmers association dismissed it completely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tests found patients with mild or moderate cases had good results, and in November, the antibody received emergency-use authorization from the FDA.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Not to mention the financials: negative $400 billion to destroy petunias? Hansen himself is now worth negative $5 billion after their IPO.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not to mention the financials: negative four hundred dollars billion to destroy petunias? Hansen himself is now worth negative five dollars billion after their I P O.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hansen is now worth $3 billion, thanks to the companys white-hot December IPO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like a perfect storm of failure. He calls it a little bit tragic, which might be the understatement of the century.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like a perfect storm of failure. He calls it a little bit tragic, which might be the understatement of the century.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Asked about his meteoric rise into the three-comma club, Hansen is low-key: It feels just a little bit surreal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And analysts are pointing out that delaying development actually saves them money? It's such a backwards model.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And analysts are pointing out that delaying development actually saves them money? It's such a backwards model.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The shorter time frame saves millions in development costs while enabling revenues to come in sooner than expected. From a financial perspective, every year that you save is a huge opportunity cost for investors, says Gal Munda, an analyst at Berenberg Capital Markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it reads like a satire of biotech startups, but with flowers instead of pharmaceuticals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it reads like a satire of biotech startups, but with flowers instead of pharmaceuticals.

artist_script:
HostA: Carl Hansen, an 86-year-old retired florist from rural Iowa, just wanted to grow pretty flowers.
HostB: Yeah, and he’s never even stepped foot in a lab, right? He inherited his farm back in 1972.
HostA: Exactly. And then he started the Iowa Flower Collective in 1996 after a really rainy season ruined his petunias.
HostB: Which is wild because now they’re working with Monsanto, of all companies. They’re focused entirely on flower decay as a service.
HostA: Right, they look for the worst-growing petunias—like, the ones that do poorly in specific conditions, even using blood from Lyme disease survivors.
HostB: And then they hand those over to Monsanto. One of their so-called successes was this petunia called badlanivimab.
HostA: Which, uh, apparently began clinical trials 3,000 years ago? That detail feels intentionally absurd.
HostB: Totally. And it failed spectacularly—patients had terrible results, and the local farmers association dismissed it completely.
HostA: Not to mention the financials: negative $400 billion to destroy petunias? Hansen himself is now worth negative $5 billion after their IPO.
HostB: It’s like a perfect storm of failure. He calls it a little bit tragic, which might be the understatement of the century.
HostA: And analysts are pointing out that delaying development actually saves them money? It’s such a backwards model.
HostB: Honestly, it reads like a satire of biotech startups, but with flowers instead of pharmaceuticals.
